statement.text: Agency costs in capital budgeting arise from conflicts of interest between managers and shareholders, potentially leading to investment decisions that maximize managerial benefit rather than NPV.
statement.formal: Actual Investment ≠ Optimal Investment when Manager Utility ≠ f(NPV)

explanation.intuition: Managers are people with their own interests - job security, power, prestige, bonuses. Sometimes these interests align with shareholders' goal of maximizing value, but sometimes they don't. This misalignment creates agency costs.
explanation.key_insight: A project with positive NPV might still be rejected if it threatens managers' positions, or a negative NPV project might be accepted if it increases managers' power or compensation.
explanation.technical_details: Agency theory predicts managers may overinvest (empire building) when they benefit from controlling more assets, or underinvest in risky projects when they bear career risk but don't share proportionally in success. Governance mechanisms like incentive compensation, monitoring, and capital budgeting controls can reduce but not eliminate agency costs.
common_misconceptions: Good managers don't have agency conflicts - all humans have self-interest
Stock options perfectly align interests - they can encourage excessive risk-taking
Agency costs only apply to large firms - they exist in any principal-agent relationship

definitions_glossary.agency_costs: Costs arising from conflicts between principals (shareholders) and agents (managers)
definitions_glossary.empire_building: Manager tendency to pursue growth and size over value maximization
definitions_glossary.managerial_entrenchment: Actions that make managers harder to replace regardless of performance
definitions_glossary.free_cash_flow_problem: Tendency to waste cash on poor projects when monitoring is weak
definitions_glossary.residual_loss: Value lost due to imperfect alignment despite governance mechanisms

sources.citation: Jensen, M., & Meckling, W. (1976). Theory of the Firm: Managerial Behavior, Agency Costs and Ownership Structure. Journal of Financial Economics, 3(4), 305-360.
sources.contribution: Foundational paper on agency theory in corporate finance

sources.citation: Jensen, M. (1986). Agency Costs of Free Cash Flow, Corporate Finance, and Takeovers. American Economic Review, 76(2), 323-329.
sources.contribution: Application of agency theory to capital budgeting and investment

learning_objectives: Identify potential agency conflicts in capital budgeting
Explain how managerial incentives affect investment decisions
Design governance mechanisms to align manager and shareholder interests
Analyze the trade-off between agency costs and governance costs

agency_problems_in_npv.description: Managers prefer larger organizations for prestige and power
agency_problems_in_npv.symptom: Accepting negative NPV acquisitions or expansion projects
agency_problems_in_npv.solution: Link compensation to value creation metrics (EVA, TSR)

agency_problems_in_npv.description: Managers avoid career risk even when shareholders would accept it
agency_problems_in_npv.symptom: Rejecting positive NPV but risky projects
agency_problems_in_npv.solution: Provide upside incentives that share success proportionally

agency_problems_in_npv.description: Focus on quarterly earnings over long-term value
agency_problems_in_npv.symptom: Cutting profitable R&D or capex to meet short-term targets
agency_problems_in_npv.solution: Long-term incentive plans, restricted stock, clawback provisions

agency_problems_in_npv.description: Championing personally favored projects regardless of NPV

governance_mechanisms: Capital budgeting controls and approval thresholds
